title: Relocating for Retirement? Here's What You Need to Know
text:
Relocating for Retirement? Here's What You Need to Know By Scott Gamm | 08/05/15 - 12:28 PM EDT Reprint 
NEW YORK (MainStreet) -- Relocating for retirement involves a slew of costs, aside from just hiring movers. Experts say retirees tend to move with the goal of downsizing - that is, buying a cheaper home to bolster their retirement savings cushion. But that doesn't always pan out. "In many instances, the cost of the new home is greater than expected," said Denis Horrigan, partner at Farmington, Conn.-based Connecticut Wealth Management. "When newly retired couples buy a new home, they include everything they wished was in their old home, like granite countertops. All of a sudden that expected windfall from downsizing has disappeared."With this in mind, identify a few target cities. Closely research the cost of living in these areas, from real estate prices to insurance costs. "Be prepared to spend more on insurance costs," said Sara Stanich, a New York-based Certified Financial Planner practitioner at Raymond James Financial Services. "People I've seen relocate to Florida from the northeast and pay higher car and property insurance rates."Meanwhile, health care costs, regardless of one's location, remain a huge unknown, especially for retirees who will likely need more health care going forward. "With the health care landscape changing dramatically as the Affordable Care Act continues to roll out and insurance providers merge, it is important to see what the coverage would be in the new location and work that into cash flow projections and budget for life in the new locale," Horrigan added, referring to Anthem's ( ANTM - Get Report ) acquisition of Cigna ( CIG - Get Report ) and Aetna's ( AET - Get Report ) merger with Humana ( HUM - Get Report ) , all announced in July.
